text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- Finnish Condeferation of Salaried Employees (STTK) suggests shorter working hours and a two-year deal with salary increases as basis for next round of pay talks.
- Finnish forest industry wants paper industry's pollution emissions to be published also in rival countries.
- Finnish regional telephone operators in Finnet alliance have set a timetable to form nationwide concern by year-end. @
- Military professionals have a more macho lifestyle than others; alcohol more frequently cause of death than elsewhere.
KAUPPALEHTI
- Finland will make its own EMU decision regardless of Sweden; staying outside EMU would rise interest rates in Finland, Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen says.
- Investment analysts are forecasting company results more accurately, a study shows.
- Diversity of analysts' forecasts on Metsa-Serla's results was suprisingly wide -- shows wrong information was out there, Aare Metsavirta, deputy CEO of Metsa-Serla says. @
- Profitability of construction industry companies is improving, but quality of construction work remains a big problem, a construction sector report says.

- Turnover of so-called new-media companies (information technology, advertising, computer programming and publishing) will double this year, even though one third of the companies are unprofitable, study shows.
- Municipalities must restructure to survive in the future, says Jukka-Pekka Alanen, director of Municipality Federation. @
AAMULEHTI
- Finns spend eight billion markka yearly on money gambling games.
- Undeclared pay totalling 10 million markka was found in suprise raids on construction sites by Construction Trade Union.
TURUN SANOMAT
- UPM-Kymmene's holding in shipyard Finnyards is only a mid-term state of affairs -- the company will concentrate on forestry, says Martin Granholm, deputy CEO of UPM-Kymmene.
- Forestries' chances to rise pulp prices remain poor. @
- Finnish forest industry invested almost 800 million markka in environment protection in 1996.
- Finnish cargo shipping company Finnlines' subsidiary Finncarriers is moving its rail-ship transport functions from Hanko to Turku.
HUFVUDSTADSBLADET

- Finnair will aim to boost market share in Sweden in next couple of years -- after that the focus is on the Baltic countries and then maybe St Petersburg in the year 2005, Eero Ahola, director of foreign relations at Finnair says.
-- Nora Hallberg, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 292
